Synaptic Package Manager
Packages
Software
Introduction
The &app; is a graphical frontend to the apt package management system. It allows you to perform all actions of the command line tool apt-get in a graphical environment.
The software on your system is organizied in so called packages. The &app; enables you to install, remove or upgrade software packages. A detailed list of the most important features can be found below.
The modifications are not executed instantly. This allows you to queue several modifications and execute them at once.
&app; provides the following features:
Install, remove, configure, upgrade and downgrade single and multiple packages.
Upgrade your whole system.
Manage package repositories.
Search list of known packages by name, description...
Filter list of shown packages by status, section, property and tag.
Arrange list of shown packages by initial letter, status or tag.
Displays all available online documentation related to a package.
Root rights are required to execute changes in the package system.
You can start &app; in the following ways:
GNOME Applications menu
Choose
System Tools Software .
KDE menu
Choose
Settings Software .
Command line
To start &app; from a command line type the following , then press Return:
synaptic
Your system can be damaged or rendered unusable.
Always use &app; with care.
The Main Window
Overview
When you start &app;, the following window is displayed.
&app; Start Up Window
Shows &app; main window. Contains titlebar, menubar, toolbar, display area, and scrollbars. Menubar contains File, View, Settings, and Help menus.
&app; Window Components
Component Description
Menubar
Contains menus that you use to perform in &app;.
Toolbar
Provides global actions (update, upgrade and execute) and a package search field.
Package list
Lists available packages. The list can be narrowed down using filters.
Package details
Provides information about a selected package
Statusbar
Displays global informations about the status of &app;
Toolbar
The toolbar provides access to global actions and a quick search for packages.
&app; toolbar
Shows the toolbar of the &app; main window
Global Actions
Update List
Query all package sources (repositories) and rebuild the list of known packages.
Upgrade System
Queue all packages with a later version available than installed for upgrade.
Execute
Execute all queued changes.
Find Field
Jump to the fist package in the list whose name matches the entry.
For detailed instructions on the quick search, see .
Package List
The package list shows all known packages by default. You can apply filters to narrow down the list of shown packages, see .
Package List
Shows the package list in the &app; main window.
To arrange the packages you can choose the following modes from View menu:
View Modes
View
Description
Flat list
List all packages non hierarchically.
Alphabetic tree
Group the packages by their initial name letter.
Section tree
Group the packages by their section, e.g. "admin", "base", "gnome", etc.
Status tree
Group the packages by their status, e.g. "installed", "not installed", "obsolete" etc.
Tag tree
Group the packages by their tag. Tags are keywords provided by third parity. Only Debian GNU/Linux with installed "debtag" supports this feature.
The column order and the used colours can be changed in the preferences, see .
Package Details
The package details area gives you detailed information about the selected package and also provides controls to modify the status of the package.
Package Details
Shows the package details in the &app; main window.
The information notebook contains the following tabs:
Information notebook
Package controls
Managing Packages
Finding Packages
Finding a package in the list of shown packages
To find a package name in the list of shown packages perform the following steps:
Type the name or a part of it into the
located in the toolbar. &app; will automatically jump to the first matching package in the list.
To find the next matching package press the the forward button next to the find field.
To begin the search again from the beginning of the package list click on the upward button.
Showing only searched packages
To only show matching packages in the package list perform the following steps:
Open the search dialog Package Find... from the menu or press Ctrl F.
Type the search expression into the find field, e.g. "mp3 ogg player".
Select the fields that you want to search in, e.g. "name" and "description"
Click on Find to start the search. In our example only music players and related packages will be listed.
You can create more complex filters with the .
Installing Packages
To install one or more packages perform the following steps:
Query the package repositories for the latest version of the package(s):
Choose Actions Update from the menu.
Click on Update in the toolbar.
Press the key combination CtrlU.
Select the package that you wish to install in the with a left mouse click. To select further packages hold down the Ctrl key while left clicking on the additional package.
Queue the selected packages for installation:
Click on Install in the package control area.
Choose Package Install from the menu.
Right click on the package and choose Install from the context menu.
Press the key combination CtrlI.
Execute the queued changes to actually install the package(s):
Click on Execute in the toolbar.
Choose Actions Execute from the menu.
Press the key combination CtrlE.
Removing Packages
To remove one or more packages follow these steps:
Select the package that you wish to remove in the with a left click. To select further packages hold down the Ctrl key while left clicking on the additional package.
Queue the selected package(s) for removal:
Click on Remove in the package control area.
Choose Package Remove from the menu.
Right click on the package and choose Remove from the context menu.
Press the key combination CtrlR.
Execute the queued changes to actually remove the package(s):
Click on Execute in the toolbar.
Choose Actions Execute from the menu.
Press the key combination CtrlE.
Configuration files and user created data (e.g. a Website in /var/www) are not removed from the system by default. You can change this behavior in the .
Alternativly, choose PackagesPurge with Configuration from the menu to remove all files related to the package.
Upgrading Single Packages
To upgrade one or more packages follow these steps:
Query the package repositories for the latest version of the package(s):
Choose Actions Update Package List from the menu.
Click on Update List in the toolbar.
Press the key combination CtrlU.
Select the package that you wish to upgrade in the . To select further packages hold down the Ctrl key while left clicking on the additional package.
Queue the selected packages for upgrade:
Click on Upgrade in the package control area.
Choose Package Upgrade from the menu.
Right click on the package and choose Upgrade from the context menu.
Execute the queued changes to actually upgrade the package(s):
Click on Execute in the toolbar.
Choose Actions Execute from the menu.
Press the key combination CtrlE.
To upgrade all installed packages to the latest version, see .
Upgrading System
The global upgrade enables you to upgrade your system to the latest version without having to queue each package upgrade manually.
&app; provides two global upgrade methods:
Upgrade
The default upgrade method queues upgrades of installed packages only. If the later version of a package depends on not installed packages or conflicts with an already installed package, the upgrade will not be queued.
Dist-Upgrade
Dist-Upgrade tries to resolve package conflicts intelligently. This includes installing additional required packages and prefering packages with higher priority.
Upgrades to later operating system major releases have to be done with the dist-upgrade method, e.g. from Conectiva 9 to Conectiva 10 or from Debian Woody to Debian Sarge.
To upgrade your system to the latest version follow these steps:
Query the package repositories for the latest version of the packages:
Choose Actions Update Package List from the menu.
Click on Update List in the toolbar.
Press the key combination CtrlU.
Queue the package(s) for upgrade:
Click on Upgrade System in the toolbar.
Choose Actions Upgrade System from the menu.
Press the key combination CtrlG.
Choose the upgrade method. Dist-upgrade is recommended.
Execute the queued changes to actually upgrade the package(s):
Click on Execute in the toolbar.
Choose Actions Execute from the menu.
Press the key combination CtrlE.
You can change the default upgrade method in the .
Downgrading Packages
This may render your package system unusable!
Downgrading packages is a broken feature, since apt and &app; can only handle conflicts and dependency resolution in upgrades. You may need this feature in some circumstances, but it is not recommended to use.
To downgrade a package you have to select a specific version of the package:
Select the package that you wish to downgrade in the .
Open the Expert tab in the detail area.
Choose the version to be installed from the list.
Execute the queued changes to actually downgrade the package(s):
Click on Execute in the toolbar.
Choose Actions Execute from the menu.
Press the key combination CtrlE.
Executing Queued Changes
To execute queued changes:
Click on Execute in the toolbar.
Choose Actions Execute from the menu.
Press the key combination CtrlE.
To show only packages with queued changes in the package list apply the "Queued Changes" filter.
Undoing Queued Changes
To undo a queued change you have the following ways:
Remove package from queue
To remove a package from the queue:
Right click on package and choose No Changes from the context menu.
Select package with a left mouse click and choose No Changes from the package control. To select further packages hold down the Ctrl key while left clicking on the additional package.
Select package(s) and press Ctrl N.
Clear all queued changes
Choose Actions Clear All Queued Changes from the menu.
Undo last change
Choose Actions Undo from the menu.
Configuring Package
Debian provides a unified configuration interface for packages, so called debconf.
To configure a supported package:
Select the package that you wish to configure in the .
Click on Configure in the package control.
This feature requires the installation of "libgnome-perl".
Getting Additional Package Documentation
asdasd
Select the package from that you wish to read additional documentation in the .
Click on Documentation in the package control.
This feature requires the installation of "dwww".
Fixing Broken Packages
Errors in the dependencies of packages or during executing changes can break the dependencies structure.
&app; will not allow any further changes on a broken system.
To correct the broken packages choose Actions Fix Broken Packages from the menu.
Managing Package Sources
Updating List of Available Packages
Choose Actions Update Package List from the menu.
Click on Update List in the toolbar.
Managing Repositories
You can edit, add and delete repositories in the repository preferences.
Open the repository editor with Preferences Repositories from the menu.
Using Package Archives on CD-ROM
Using Filters
Applying Filters
Filters enable you to narrow down the list of shown packages.
&app; comes with a set of predefined filters.
Predefined Filters
Filter Description
All packages
Display all known packages.
Install
Display only currently installed packages.
Not installed
Display only currently not installed packages.
Upgradable
Display only packages with a later version available.
Broken
Display only packages with broken dependencies.
Programmed Changes
Display only packages queued to be modified.
New in archive
Display only new packages since the last repository update.
Residual
Display only former installed packages that left data or configuration files on the system.
Pkg with Debconf
Display only packages that can be configured through the debian package configuration system, so called debconf.
Obsolete or locally installed
Display only packages that are not (for longer) included in one of the specified repositories.
Search Filter
Display the last results of the advanced package package search, see .
To apply a filter:
Choose ViewApply Filter Filter.
Choose the filter from the Show combobox in the main window.
Editing and Creating Filters
Filters can be created, deleted and modified in the filter editor:
Choose from the menu View Edit Filters....
Click on Filters... in the main window.
Edit Filters
Shows the filter editor.
The filter editor contains the following components:
List of Filter
Shows a list of available filters.
View
Specify the arrangement of the results.
Rules
Rules allow you to define which packages should be shown in the list. A package has to fulfil all selected criterions.
Status
Allows you to select packages by their status.
Section
Allows you to select packages by their section.
Properties
Keywords
Keywords are based on debtags. Only Debian GNU/Linux with installed "debtags" supports this feature.
Preferences
General
The general preferences include the following settings:
General
Allow regular expressions in searches and filters
Regular expression are an advanced method of text matching.
Consider recommended packages as dependencies
Regular expression are an advanced method of text matching.
Actions
Show terminal window while executing
Regular expression are an advanced method of text matching.
Ask to quit after the changes have been executed
Regular expression are an advanced method of text matching.
Remove package
Regular expression are an advanced method of text matching.
Upgrade method
Regular expression are an advanced method of text matching.
Number of undo operations
Regular expression are an advanced method of text matching.
Confirm actions also affecting other packages
Regular expression are an advanced method of text matching.
Layout
You can change the appearance of Synaptic.
Main Window
Choose between two different layouts of the main window.
Fonts
Specify custom fonts for the application and the terminal output.
Column Order and Colours
Modify the appearance of the package list in the main window.
Column Order
Order the columns of the package list. A value of -1 hides the column.
Colours
Assign colors to visualize the package status.
Temporary Files
Configure the management of completely or partially downloaded package files.
Network
Configure the internet connection and proxy server.
Expert
Undocumented.
Known Bugs and Limitations
Known issues and workarounds
Problem Workaround
Unsupported locale
Use a locale supported by Xlib.
A failed installation blocks further operations in synaptic
Under some rare circumstances the actual installation or removal of a package can fail. As a consequence all other queued changes are canceled, too.
&app; requires a clear environment with no half installed packages to perform additional changes. But at the moment there is no way to continue canceled installations within &app;.
To fix this situation type the following command in a terminal, then press Return:
apt-get install -f
Keyboard Shortcuts
List of all global short cuts in &app;:
CtrlE
Execute all queued changes.
CtrlF
Open the package find dialog.
CtrlG
Queue all possible upgrades.
CtrlI
Queue the selected package(s) for installation.
CtrlN
Ignore any queued changes and set package as before.
CtrlF
Open the package find dialog.
CtrlG
Queue the whole system for upgrade.
CtrlI
Queue the selected package(s) for installation.
CtrlN
Ignore any queued changes and set package as before.
CtrlQ
Quit &app;.
CtrlR
Queue the selected package(s) for removal.
CtrlU
Update the list of known package.
